description: From Middle English regretten, regreten, from Old French regreter, regrater (â€œto lamentâ€), from re- (intensive prefix) + *greter, *grater (â€œto weepâ€), from Frankish *grÄtan (â€œto weep, mourn, lamentâ€), from Proto-Germanic *grÄ“tanÄ… (â€œto weepâ€), from Proto-Indo-European *ÇµÊ°rehâ‚d- (â€œto soundâ€); and Frankish *greutan (â€œto cry, weepâ€), from Proto-Germanic *greutanÄ… (â€œto weep, cryâ€), from Proto-Indo-European *gÊ°rewd- (â€œto weep, be sadâ€), equivalent to re- +â€ greet. Cognate with Old High German grÄzan (â€œto cryâ€), Old English grÇ£tan (â€œto weep, greetâ€), Old English grÄ“otan (â€œto weep, lamentâ€), Old Norse grÃ¡ta (â€œto weep, groanâ€), Gothic ğŒ²ğ‚ğŒ´ğ„ğŒ°ğŒ½ (grÄ“tan, â€œto weepâ€). More at greet.

entries.meaning: Emotional pain on account of something done or experienced in the past, with a wish that it had been different; a looking back with dissatisfaction or with longing.
examples: What man does not remember with regret the first time he read Robinson Crusoe?

entries.meaning: (decision theory) The amount of avoidable loss that results from choosing the wrong action.

verbs.description: regret (third-person singular simple present regrets, present participle regretting, simple past and past participle regretted)

entries.meaning: To feel sorry about (a thing that has or has not happened), afterthink: to wish that a thing had not happened, that something else had happened instead.
(more generally) To feel sorry about (any thing).
examples: I regret that I have to do this, but I don't have a choice.

entries.meaning: (archaic, transitive) To miss; to feel the loss or absence of; to mourn.
examples: He more than ever regretted his home, and with increased desire longed to see his family.
